Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story:
I gripped the steering wheel, my eyes darting between the snow-slicked road and the anxious passenger in my back seat. The winter storm had turned the city into a maze of brake lights and slush, and every minute lost in traffic felt like a personal failure. My passenger kept checking his watch, reminding me that his international flight wouldn’t wait. I wanted to reassure him, to promise I’d get him there on time, but the roads were treacherous and safety had to come first.

At every red light, my mind drifted to the code sample my mentor had assigned. Three days to finish it, but I’d barely started. The expectation was clear: deliver quality work, show initiative, prove I was worth mentoring. But after these long shifts behind the wheel, exhaustion clung to me like the damp from my boots. I worried I’d let my mentor down, that I’d show up to our next meeting empty-handed.

The pressure from both sides pressed in on me—my passenger’s urgent need, my mentor’s trust. I felt torn, wishing I could split myself in two, fulfill both roles perfectly. The snow kept falling, and I kept driving, caught between the demands of the road and the silent ticking of my own deadline.
